Non-thermal plasma-catalytic ammonia synthesis (NTPCAS) has been regarded as a promising route to store hydrogen by utilizing renewable electricity. Alumina is a suitable support of the catalysts in NTPCAS and its properties can influence the performance of catalysts remarkably. In this study, the influence of the alumina calcination temperatures (T c) on the catalytic performance of Fe-Al-x (x represents the value of T c) was analyzed in a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor for NTPCAS. The results suggested that an increase in T c transforms the alumina crystalline from γ phase to α phase. The best performance with a synthesized ammonia concentration of 11833 ppm was achieved over Fe-Al-900 with coexisting γ and θ phases of alumina under N2: H2 = 1:1 and SEI = 37.05 kJ/L conditions, which was 37 % higher than that of Fe-Al-800 with only γ phase. In addition, the larger T c (i.e. 1100 and 1200 °C) decreased the specific surface area, increased the mean catalyst particle size, and led to the non-uniform dispersion of Fe species. The NH3-TPD and XPS studies suggested that an increase in T c could influence the surface acidity and oxygen vacancy concentration of Fe catalysts, which were crucial to adjusting the catalytic activity for NTPCAS. This study clarifies the value of a suitable design of support of catalysts for improving NTPCAS. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia synthesis Non-thermal plasma catalysis Alumina crystalline Calcination temperature Fe catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In recent few years, the utilization of renewable energy power such as water, wind, and solar power has gained significant attention. However, integrating intermittent and stochastic renewable energy power into the power grid poses various problems to the electricity grid operating [1,2]. Developing energy storage technology is a promising alternative to integrating renewable energy electricity into the power grid. Among various energy storage technologies, hydrogen production via water electrolysis is a highly potential method in large-scale applications for consuming renewable energy power [3]. However, the storage and transportation conditions of H2 have been a great challenge because a mature and low-cost storage and transportation infrastructure has not been established [4,5]. Ammonia with a high hydrogen capacity of 17.7 wt.% and a high energy density of 3 kWh kg-1 [6,7] is a widely-used industrial chemical with mature storage and transportation infrastructures and is much more readily liquefied compared to hydrogen given that ammonia and hydrogen liquefy at -33.4 °C and -253 °C, respectively [8], making it an efficient hydrogen storage media. In conclusion, the distributed ammonia synthesis utilizing renewable energy power to store hydrogen is an increasingly significant attention. Generally, NH3 is centrally produced on a large scale by the traditional Haber-Bosch (H-B) process with catalysts under harsh temperature and pressure (e.g., 730 K and 20 MPa, respectively) conditions [9], which is inevitably considered as a highly energy-intensive industry with close to 2 % energy consumption and 1.8 % CO2 emission worldwide yearly [10] and is difficult to adapt to the distributed ammonia synthesis powered by renewable energy electricity. Therein, it is urgent to explore an alternative ammonia synthesis technology using a green and sustainable method for hydrogen storage. Currently, a considerable number of novel technologies on ammonia synthesis under mild pressure and temperature have been reported, such as non-thermal plasma (NTP) catalysis [11-16], photocatalysis [17], and electrocatalysis [18,19]. Among these technologies, NTP-catalytic ammonia synthesis (NTPCAS) has gained increasing attention because of its high NH3 synthesis rate, which can adapt well to the distributed ammonia production, and can be switched on or off instantly to adapt to the intermittency and stochasticity of renewable energy power [11,20]. Catalysts play a crucial part in the performance of NTPCAS, and various catalysts have been utilized in this field in the past two decades [21,22]. According to these studies, metal-carrier catalysts have gained wide concern due to their combination of porous carriers and metal active sites. Iron and nickel catalysts showed enormous potential among non-precious metal-carrier catalysts. The study by Hu et al. [23] showed that 10Fe/CeO2 exhibited an ammonia synthesis rate comparable to 2Ru/CeO2 without external heat in a DBD reactor. In the research by Meloni et al. [24], 10 %wt. Ni-γAl2O3 had a better ammonia yield than 0.5 %wt. Ru-γAl2O3 with the power of the electric field from 11 W to 66 W. Wang et al. [25] achieved NTPCAS with a water-electrode using packing alumina-supported transition metal (Fe, Ni, and Cu) catalysts in a DBD reactor under near room temperature and atmospheric pressure conditions. The energy efficiency and NH3 synthesis rate increased in the order: Fe/Al2O3 < Cu/Al2O3 < Ni/Al2O3. In the research by Liu et al. [26], Fe/BaTiO3, Co/BaTiO3, and Ni/BaTiO3 catalysts noticeably improved the performance of NTPCAS, and the best catalyst was Ni/BaTiO3. Recent evidence suggests that Ni-based catalysts are the most efficient among non-precious metal catalysts for NTPCAS. Nonetheless, Fe-based catalysts give a possibility for large-scale industrial applications in NTPCAS owing to the lower cost and significant historical role in industrial ammonia production. The existing research on ammonia synthesis suggested that the types and properties of catalyst supports played a critical part in the catalytic activity of ammonia synthesis [27-33]. For instance, studies by Zhou et al. [29] showed a significant difference in NH3 concentration between Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 under various operation conditions and discovered the type of support affects NTPCAS significantly. Lin et al. [31] found that steam treatment led to a larger pore volume and surface area of carbon supports, which influenced the catalytic activity of Ru catalysts in ammonia synthesis. In addition, alumina is frequently selected as catalyst support owing to its large specific surface area, low production cost, and adjustable properties [30,34], and the property of alumina could be adjusted via calcining at different temperatures [35-37]. Lin et al [30] reported that transforming the crystalline phase of alumina supports via calcination at different temperatures influenced the performance of Ru/Al2O3 in thermal-catalytic ammonia synthesis. However, to our knowledge there is no work has been devoted to the impact of the adjustable properties of alumina support on the catalytic activity in NTPCAS. This study aims to offer insights into the influence of alumina calcination temperature (T c) on the catalytic performance of Fe catalysts in NTPCAS. Firstly, the alumina with different properties was obtained via calcining at various temperatures (800 °C, 900 °C, 1100 °C, and 1200 °C) and served as a support of Fe catalysts. The impregnation method was used to obtain different alumina-loaded Fe catalysts (Fe-Al-x, where x is the value of T c). The effects of the support properties of alumina calcined under different temperatures on the synthesized ammonia concentration and energy efficiency using Fe-Al catalysts in NTPCAS were investigated in a DBD reactor without heating under atmospheric pressure at different N2: H2 ratios and specific energy inputs (SEI). In addition, the modified properties of the alumina-supported Fe catalysts via changing T c were elucidated by various characterization methods (e.g. XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and XPS). This study presented guidance for the design of a high-activity and cost-effective catalyst via adjusting the support properties of alumina-supported Fe catalysts and could promote the industrialization of NTPCAS. 2 Experimental section 2.1 The preparation of iron catalysts Commercial nano alumina (Al2O3, MACKLIN, 99.99 %) was calcined in air at 800 °C, 900 °C, 1100 °C, and 1200 °C for 4 h to obtain the alumina with different properties. The samples after calcination are denoted as Al2O3-x in this study, where x is T c. The incipient wetness impregnation method was used to prepare the Fe-Al-x catalysts with 5 wt.% Fe loading. At first, the Iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Aladdin, 99.99 %) was dissolved in the deionized water (InnoChem) to form a uniform solution. Then, the solution was added to Al2O3-x (2 g) to form a homogeneous slurry. The slurry was stirred for 2 h at 50 °C and then aged overnight. Next, it was dried for 12 h at 110 °C and calcined for 5 h at 500 °C. The as-prepared samples were granulated into particles with a size range of 100-200 mesh, which were named as Fe-Al-x catalysts (unreduced samples). Fe-Al-x was reduced in an Ar/H2 (100 mL/min; Ar/H2 = 1:1) plasma for 2 h before conducting NTPCAS. Before characterization, the reduced samples were treated in a pure Ar flow (50 mL/min) for 2h and in a 0.5 vol.% O2/Ar flow (50 mL/min) for 3h at ambient temperature to deactivate. 2.2 Experimental setup The experiments were conducted in the experimental setup designed by Zhou et al. [29] shown in Fig. S1 using Fe-Al-x catalysts under atmospheric pressure without heating. The high-voltage electrode was a stainless-steel rod attached to a pulse AC power supply (CTP-2000KP, Suman), which was coaxially placed in a quartz tube. The ground electrode was a copper mesh and was wrapped around the quartz tube. The space between the high-voltage electrode and the quartz tube was filled with Fe catalyst (0.5 mL, 100-200 mesh). The quantity of charges accumulated in the DBD reactor was determined using the voltage on an external capacitor, which was measured via a voltage probe (Rigol PVP3150). These signals were detected and displayed on an oscilloscope (Rigol DS1102). An optical fiber thermometer (AT-YG-KG1) was used to measure the temperature of the catalysts in the quartz tube. A homogeneous mixture of N2 (99.999 %) and H2 (99.999 %) was introduced into the DBD reactor for NTPCAS without heating. The gas of the outlet was detected via a Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. The influence of N2: H2 ratio (1:3-3:1) and total gas flow rate (20-200 mL/min) on the synthesized ammonia concentration were examined under a constant discharge power of 24.7W. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested by an X-ray diffractometer (D8 ADVANCE) with the 2θ range from 10° to 90 ° at a rate of 5 °/min. A GEMINI300 microscope was used to perform Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis was carried out using a TALOS F200S microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The specific surface areas of catalysts were tested via the BET method by the automated gas adsorption Instrument (Quanta chrome NOVA 2000e). The mass fraction of the Fe in the catalysts was determined by an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer (Avio 500). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was examined by a DIONEX AQUION instrument. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) analysis and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis were both carried out using a chemical adsorption analyzer (PCA-1200, BUILDER). For NH3-TPD, 200 mg catalysts were pretreated in a 10 vol.% H2/Ar flow (30 mL/min) at 450 °C for 1.5 h. The reduced catalysts were purged with a pure Ar flow (30 mL/min) at 450 °C for 0.5 h and then cooled to 100 °C in the same Ar flow. The samples were exposed to 10 vol.% NH3/Ar (30 mL/min) at 100 °C for 1.5 h to reach ammonia adsorption saturation state over catalysts. After that, the pure Ar flow was used to remove the physisorbed NH3 at 100 °C for 0.5 h. Finally, the samples were heated from 100 °C to 700 °C for desorption tests and the number of the desorbed ammonia was measured via a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For H2-TPR, 50 mg unreduced Fe-Al-x catalysts were pretreated in a pure Ar flow (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 25 °C. Next, the catalysts were heated from 25 °C to 900 °C in a 10 vol.% H2/Ar flow (30 mL/min) for reduction, and the amount of the consumed H2 was also measured by the TCD. 2.4 The calculation of parameters The discharge power is calculated using Eq. (4): (4) P d ( W ) = f × C e × A where f is power supply frequency (0.2 kHz), C e is external capacitance (0.47 μF), and A is the area of the Q-U Lissajous figure. The specific energy input is calculated by Eq. (5): (5) S E I ( kJ / L ) = 60 × P d Q gas where Q gas (mL/min) is the total gas flow rate of the inlet. The NH3 synthesis rate and energy efficiency are calculated using Eqs. (6) and Eq. (7): (6) N H 3 synthesis rate ( μ mol g − 1 h − 1 ) = 60 × C × Q out 24 × 1000 × m c (7) E N H 3 ( g kW h − 1 ) = 60 × 17 × C × Q out 24 × 1000000 × P d where C (ppm) is the synthesized ammonia concentration, m c (g) is the mass of the filled catalysts, assuming that m c is equal to the mass of Fe-Al-900 (0.3 g) under "only plasma" conditions, to compare the ammonia synthesis rate more conveniently. Q out is the total gas flow rate of the outlet, the “24” is the gas molar volume at ambient pressure and temperature, the “17” is molar mass of NH3 and the “1000” and “1000000” is the unit conversion coefficients. The NH3 flow rate ( Q N H 3 ) and energy consumption (EC) are calculated using Eqs. (8) and Eq. (9) [38]: (8) Q N H 3 ( mL / min ) = C / 1000000 × Q gas 1 + C / 1000000 (9) EC ( MJ mo l − 1 ) = P d Q N H 3 / 24 / 1000 / 60 × 1 0 − 6 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Fe-Al-x catalysts The XRD of the Fe-Al-x is presented in Fig. 1 . Only the diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 were detected over Fe-Al-800. For Fe-Al-900, the diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 and θ-Al2O3 both appeared, indicating the coexistence of the γ phase and θ phase of Al2O3 in Fe-Al-900. Similarly, The diffraction peaks of θ-Al2O3 and α-Al2O3 were both observed over Fe-Al-1100. For Fe-Al-1200, only the α-Al2O3 diffraction peaks were observed, indicating that the alumina had been transformed to α phase at 1200 °C. This phenomenon of phase transformation of alumina was also observed in previous literature [30,35-37]. The diffraction peaks of Fe occurred over both Fe-Al-1100 and Fe-Al-1200, while no diffraction peaks of Fe were observed over Fe-Al-800 and Fe-Al-900, which may be due to the smaller Fe particles or the better Fe dispersion on Fe-Al-800 and Fe-Al-900 [29]. The TEM and HRTEM images of the Fe-Al-x are presented in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2, respectively. According to the HRTEM results, the lattice fringes of 0.203 nm in Fe-Al-x catalysts were attributed to the (110) planes of Fe. As shown in Fig. S2(a) and (b), the lattice fringes of 0.140 nm and 0.198 nm in Fe-Al-800 and Fe-Al-900 were ascribed to the (440) planes and (400) planes of γ-Al2O3, respectively. As shown in Fig. S2(c) and (d), the lattice fringes of 0.244 nm and 0.255 nm in Fe-Al-1100 and Fe-Al-1200 were ascribed to the (111) planes of θ-Al2O3 and (104) planes of α-Al2O3, respectively. These HRTEM results agree with XRD results shown in Fig. 1. From Fig. 2, the alumina of Fe-Al-800 displayed an irregular crystallite morphology, whereas the alumina of Fe-Al-1200 exhibited large agglomerated crystals. The increased T c caused the small alumina crystallites to aggregate into a larger bulk, which is consistent with previous findings [30,39]. Therefore, the specific surface area of alumina decreased with the increase in T c, as shown in Table S1. The mean particle sizes of Fe-Al-800, Fe-Al-900, and Fe-Al-1100 catalysts were 6.19 nm, 8.84 nm, and 12.32 nm, respectively. However, the Fe-Al-1200 catalysts are inconvenient to count particle size due to their large agglomerated crystals. Nonetheless, Fig. 2 showed that the catalyst particle size increased as T c increased. An obvious agglomeration of the Fe species on the Al2O3 supports occurred in Fig. S3 (c) and (d), suggesting a non-uniform dispersion of Fe species and a relatively weak interaction between Fe and Al2O3 supports [29,40,41]. In summary, the larger T c (i.e. 1100 and 1200 °C) led to a larger catalyst particle size, a worse dispersion of Fe species and a weaker interaction between Fe and Al2O3 supports. The general properties of the Fe-Al-x are displayed in Table 1 and Fig. S4. In Fig. S4, all catalysts showed type-IV isotherms, with a sharp increase occurring in the relative pressure range of 0.6 < P/P0 < 0.9, suggesting the presence of meso-porosity in Fe catalysts [42]. As shown in Table 1, the surface areas via BET of the alumina-supported Fe catalysts decreased with T c increasing, which was consistent with Lin's study on Ru-Ba/Al2O3-x [30]. There was no significant difference in surface area for the Fe-Al-800 and Fe-Al-900, while the surface area of the Fe-Al-1100 and Fe-Al-1200 decreased by 40 % and 94 % compared to that for Fe-Al-900, respectively. The Fe mass fraction of Fe-Al-x catalysts determined by ICP analysis were 4.368 %, 4.427 %, 4.696 %, and 4.803 %, respectively. 3.2 The performance of NTPCAS over Fe-Al-x catalysts Fig. 3 illustrates the synthesized ammonia concentration and energy efficiency influenced by various N2:H2 ratios of NTPCAS at P d = 24.7 W and Q gas= 40 mL/min. The ammonia concentration increased as the ratio increased from 1:3 to 1:1, while it decreased as the N2:H2 ratio increased from 1:1 to 3:1 for the catalysts. The optimal performance occurred at N2:H2 ratio = 1:1, which was also observed in prior research [43], and it is close to the one at N2:H2 ratio = 1:2. The H2 has a lower dissociation energy compared to N2, which results in a preferential dissociation of H2 and occupation of catalyst sites, leading to the observed phenomenon [29]. Elevating T c from 800 °C to 900 °C led to a 37 % increase in the synthesized ammonia concentration at N2:H2 = 1:1, from 8633 ppm to 11833 ppm. However, the synthesized ammonia concentration using Fe-Al-1200 was only 8127 ppm, which was 45.6 % lower than the best performance using Fe-Al-900. The order of increasing NH3 concentration and energy efficiency was as follows: Fe-Al-900 > Fe-Al-1100 > Fe-Al-800 > Fe-Al-1200. The difference in the catalytic activity in NTPCAS may be owing to the variation in the properties of supports. In summary, the alumina calcination temperature plays an important role in the NTPCAS at various N2:H2 ratios. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) show the impact of SEI on the synthesized ammonia concentration and energy efficiency in NTPCAS, respectively. SEI control was achieved by adjusting the flow rate (Q gas). The NH3 concentration increased as the SEI increased but increased slowly for the catalysts except Fe-Al-1200. In the case of Fe-Al-900, there is a 185 % increase in the synthesized ammonia concentration from 4151 ppm to 11833 ppm as SEI rose from 7.41 to 37.05 kJ/L, but it only increased 13 % from 11833 ppm to 13391 ppm as SEI rose from 37.05 to 74.1 kJ/L. For Fe-Al-1200, the NH3 concentration decreased from 8127.3 ppm to 8007.9 ppm as SEI rose from 37.05 to 74.1 kJ/L. These results suggest that the NTPCAS process would be hindered under higher SEI conditions. This suppressed effect weakens over Fe-Al-900 catalysts compared to the other catalysts, which may be attributed to the increase of weak acid sites of the Fe-Al-900, as shown in Fig. 5 in Section 3.3. The influence of alumina calcination temperature on the performance of Fe-Al-x in NTPCAS varied depending on the specific SEI conditions. For instance, the ammonia concentrations of the Fe-Al-x catalysts are comparable at lower SEIs of 7.41 and 9.26 kJ/L, whereas the ammonia concentration synthesized using Fe-Al-900 shows a 67 % increase compared to that synthesized using Fe-Al-1200 at a higher SEI of 74.1kJ/L. In summary, according to Fig. 4 (a) and (b), Fe-Al-900 exhibited the best performance with SEI control, achieving an optimal synthesized NH3 concentration of 13391ppm with an energy efficiency of 0.46 gNH3kWh-1 and an optimal energy efficiency of 1.43 gNH3 kWh-1 with a synthesized ammonia concentration of 4151 ppm. Fig. 4 (c) shows the NH3 synthesis rate and energy efficiency on the performance of NTPACS with various T c under an SEI of 37.05 kJ/L and an N2:H2 ratio of 1:1. The use of Fe-Al-x catalysts showed a significant improvement in NH3 synthesis rate and energy efficiency compared to that under “only plasma” conditions. In addition, a notable discrepancy in the performance among different catalysts was observed. The NH3 synthesis rate and energy efficiency first rose and then dropped as T c rose. Fe-Al-900 had the highest NH3 synthesis rate of 3892 μmol g−1 h−1 with an energy efficiency of 0.81 gNH3 kWh-1, representing a 101.7 % increase compared to the NH3 synthesis rate of Fe-Al-1200. It was reported that the larger specific surface area provided more surface sites for free radical adsorption, leading to a higher NH3 synthesis rate [44]. Therefore, this decrease in NH3 synthesis rate from Fe-Al-900 to Fe-Al-1200 might be owing to the low specific surface area of Fe-Al-1200, as shown in Table 1. Fig. 4 (d) demonstrates that the ammonia synthesis rate and the energy efficiency of Fe-Al-900 remained constant over 5 cycles with each cycle lasting 2 h. The best catalytic performance was obtained using Fe-Al-900 in this study. The comparison of the results in our study with results from other alumina-based catalysts reported in the previous literature for NTPCAS is listed in Table 2 . Fe-Al-900 gave the best energy efficiency of 1.43 g kWh-1 with an NH3 synthesis rate of 6827 μmol g-1 h-1 at Q gas =200 mL/min, P d = 24.7 W and N2: H2 =1:1. Studies by Li et al. [45] showed that Ru/Al2O3 reached an NH3 concentration of 14900 ppm with an energy consumption of 32.39 MJ mol-1 in a DBD reactor at Q gas =120 mL/min, N2:H2 ratio = 2:1, and P d = 38.4 W. Fe-Al-900 catalyst in this study is comparable to Ru/Al2O3 in terms of the NH3 concentration. Although the energy consumption is higher than that of Ru/Al2O3, the Fe-Al-900 catalyst offers a more economical option. Compared to other non-precious metal catalysts listed in Table 2, the Fe-Al-900 catalyst demonstrated a significant advantage in terms of ammonia synthesis rate. Therefore, the Fe-Al-900 catalyst provides competitive energy efficiency and a high ammonia synthesis rate, which guides the design of suitable catalysts for NTPCAS. 3.3 Effects of alumina calcination temperature on properties of Fe-Al-x catalysts The acid sites of the Fe-Al-x were determined using NH3-TPD. Fig. 5 exhibits the NH3 peaks of weak acid sites (125−260 °C), medium acid sites (260−490 °C), and strong acid sites (490−900 °C) [25,29]. The number of ammonia adsorbed on weak acid sites of Fe-Al-x catalysts listed in Table 3 was given in the order: 100 μmol/g, 94 μmol/g, 65 μmol/g, and 13 μmol/g from Fe-Al-800 to Fe-Al-1200, respectively, which is essential for ammonia synthesis [15,25,29,51]. For example, weak acid sites have been proven to be beneficial for NTPCAS by enhancing the form of NH2 intermediates [25] and reducing the adsorption of synthesized ammonia from the surface of the catalyst [15,29]. Consequently, Fe-Al-900 gives a high NH3 synthesis rate as shown in Fig. 4 (c). However, Fe-Al-800, despite having a comparable number of weak acid sites, did not perform well due to its higher concentrations of medium acid sites and strong acid sites, which hindered the desorption of synthesized ammonia and slowed the NH3 synthesis rate [25,51]. Overall, the alumina calcination temperature has a notable impact on the surface acidity of Fe-Al-x. The H2-TPR was conducted to analyze the interaction between metal species and supports. Fig. 6 illustrates the H2-TPR results of unreduced Fe-Al-x catalysts, which reveal interactions between iron species and alumnia. The reduction of iron oxide occurred in two stages. In the first stage, Fe2O3 was reduced to Fe3O4 at temperatures ranging from 200 to 555 °C. In the second stage, Fe3O4 was further reduced to Fe through FeO at temperatures ranging from 555 to 800 °C [52,53]. The minimum temperature for hydrogen consumption decreased as T c increased, suggesting a weaker interaction between iron species and alumina, which may lead to an increase in the metal particle size [40,41]. This is consistent with the TEM results shown in Fig. 2. The electronic properties of Fe-Al-x catalysts were studied using XPS to analyze catalysts’ chemical states and oxygen vacancies, as shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7 exhibits the O 1s spectrum of Fe-Al-x catalysts. The three peaks were named as O1, O2, and O3, representing lattice oxygen, surface chemically adsorbed oxygen, and weakly physically absorbed oxygen species [54], respectively, in different binding energies. For Fe-Al-900, the peaks of O1, O2, and O3 occurred at 530.28 eV, 531.08 eV, and 532.48 eV, respectively. Compared to the binding energy of the O2 peak of Fe-Al-800, that of Fe-Al-900, Fe-Al-1100, and Fe-Al-1200 all decreased by 0.3 eV, 0.4 eV, and 0.6 eV, respectively. The density of oxygen vacancies (OV) was indicated using the ratio of O2/(O1 + O2+ O3) [54-56]. Compared to Fe-Al-800, the concentration of OV increased by 18.75 % for Fe-Al-900. However, the concentration of OV of Fe-Al-900, Fe-Al-1100, and Fe-Al-1200 were similar. The promoting effect of OV on NTPCAS using LDH packings has been confirmed [57], and Li et al. reported that N2 molecules were activated and absorbed on the oxygen vacancies more easily for Ni/LaOF catalysts [58]. It could be inferred that catalysts with more OV would give a better performance for ammonia synthesis. In conclusion, increasing T c tended to create more OV over catalysts, which was highly beneficial for NTPCAS. It can be concluded that the best performance of the Fe-Al-900 catalyst under NTP conditions shown in Fig. 4 (c) was due to its higher oxygen vacancy concentration. However, despite having a similar OV compared to Fe-Al-900, Fe-Al-1100 and Fe-Al-1200 did not achieve high ammonia concentrations due to their low BET surface areas and poor dispersion, which suppressed the ammonia synthesis [16,44,59]. 4 Conclusion Alumina-supported Fe catalysts were prepared for NTPCAS and the catalytic performances were optimized by adjusting the phase of Al2O3 supports via different calcination temperatures. The results indicated that alumina changed its phases and properties via calcinating at different temperatures. Only γ- Al2O3 was observed in Fe-Al-800, and for Fe-Al-900, both γ-Al2O3 and θ-Al2O3 were observed. Similarly, there was a coexistence of θ phase and α phase in Fe-Al-1100. When alumina calcination temperature was raised to 1200 °C, all Al2O3 converted to α phase. The highest synthesized NH3 concentration (11833 ppm) using Fe-Al-900 with the coexistence of γ phase and θ phase was achieved in NTPCAS, which was 37 % higher than that of Fe-Al-800 with only γ phase, and 46 % higher than that of Fe-Al-1200 with only α phase. For Fe-Al-x, the larger alumina calcination temperature (i.e. 1100 and 1200 °C) led to a smaller specific surface area, a larger mean particle size, and a worse dispersion of Fe species. The characterization results showed that the catalysts using the alumina supports calcined at 900 °C owned a higher concentration of weak acid sites compared to the catalysts using alumina supports calcined at 800, 1100, and 1200 °C. However, Fe-Al-800 exhibited poor performance owing to its higher concentrations of medium acid sites and strong acid sites and lower concentration of oxygen vacancy. It is demonstrated that the utilization of alumina calcined at different temperatures as supports could affect the surface acidity, the oxygen vacancy concentration, the metal-support interaction, and the dispersion of Fe species, which is helpful in finding a suitable catalyst for NTPCAS by adjusting the properties of the support. coredata.dc:description: Non-thermal plasma-catalytic ammonia synthesis (NTPCAS) has been regarded as a promising route to store hydrogen by utilizing renewable electricity. Alumina is a suitable support of the catalysts in NTPCAS and its properties can influence the performance of catalysts remarkably. In this study, the influence of the alumina calcination temperatures (T c) on the catalytic performance of Fe-Al-x (x represents the value of T c) was analyzed in a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor for NTPCAS. The results suggested that an increase in T c transforms the alumina crystalline from γ phase to α phase. The best performance with a synthesized ammonia concentration of 11833 ppm was achieved over Fe-Al-900 with coexisting γ and θ phases of alumina under N2: H2 = 1:1 and SEI = 37.05 kJ/L conditions, which was 37 % higher than that of Fe-Al-800 with only γ phase. In addition, the larger T c (i.e. 1100 and 1200 °C) decreased the specific surface area, increased the mean catalyst particle size, and led to the non-uniform dispersion of Fe species. The NH3-TPD and XPS studies suggested that an increase in T c could influence the surface acidity and oxygen vacancy concentration of Fe catalysts, which were crucial to adjusting the catalytic activity for NTPCAS. This study clarifies the value of a suitable design of support of catalysts for improving NTPCAS.
